Accessibility.html:
Overview

Momentum has keyboard operation built into all of its components, improving the experience for visually impaired users and other users who operate using the keyboard.

The Progress Bar component has been designed to meet the accessibility guidelines.

Interaction guideance

Controls

To move focus to next element.
Progress Bar does not have interact-able element. Use arrow to focus on static elements such as text.

Screen reader

When labels are implemented, the aria-label likely will require additional context to be announced by the screen reader. Decide what should be announced for the following: name, role and value. Accessibility labels should include both the label and role.
Align the accessibility label (used for assistive technology devices like screen readers) with the visible label text (if any).

Structural Role and Initial Status not applicable

Spec.html:
Anatomy

Tokens

Spacing

Component spacing

Between the Label Text and the progress bar, there should be 8px spacing. Between the Progress Bar and the Helper Text, there should be 12px spacing.

Width

Progress bar has default minimum width of 200px but it is not fixed. The progress bar could stretch to fit the design appropriately.

Padding

There should be minimum of 12px padding around the component.
Progress bar width can adjust according to the use case.

Component spacing

Between the Label Text and the progress bar, there should be 8px spacing. Between the Progress Bar and the Helper Text, there should be 8px spacing.

Padding

There should be minimum of 12px padding around the component.
Progress bar width can adjust according to the use case.

Guidelines.html:
Anatomy

Use cases

When to use

For an operation or a process that can take a more than few seconds or unknown amount of time.
When the process can be shown with percentage.
To visually show the progression of a system operation such as downloading, uploading, loading data, submitting, or saving.

When NOT to use

When the progress is determined by user actions such as task completed, or storage space, rather than system actions If the process takes less than 5 seconds to load, use indeterminate indicator such as spinner

Types

Progress bar

Text alignment depends on the context and area given. Progress bar have Default and Inline text alignment.

Progress bar

Text alignment depends on the context and area given. Default progress bar is able to show percentage but takes up more real estate on the height.

Inline Progress bar

Text alignment depends on the context and area given. Inline can not show percentage info. It has lower height so ideal for smaller real estate.

Behavior

There is no user particular interaction once the progress bar is in progress. Progress bar behaves once the user initiates action, and will be interrupted when the progress completes or fails.

States

Active

The active progress state with a blue bar indicator, conveys that the progress is still in place.

Success

Successful loading state is conveyed by a green progress bar with a full green bar. 100% percentage is optional.

Error

The error loading state indicates that the action did not complete successfully. A helper text with brief information will appear. As soon as a process fails, the indicator barâ€™s progress spans full width, turns red, and remains visible.

Sizes

Medium (Default)

Medium size is the default height. The progress bar measures at 4px height, 18px text box height, 56px overall height. The Medium (default) progress bar height is used when being placed inside a component such as within cards, collection, menus, etc.

Large

Large progress bar measures at 8px height, 20px text box height, 64px overall height. The big progress bar height is typically used when there is large amounts of space on a page, used outside of compact components, such as Modals.

Determinate & Indeterminate

1

2

Determinate

Determinate progress indicators fill from 0 to 100% (from left to right) as the progress completes.

Indeterminate

Indeterminate progress indicators loops along the progress track continually from left to right until the process is complete.

Content

Labels

Labels inform users what information progress bar is processing.
Percentage shows the user of percentage complete, not percentage left.
Keep the label short and clear. Limit to few words and single line.
Label text should be consistent before, during and after the process.

Helper text

Helper text is used to show additional information regarding the process.
Common use cases of helper text for a progress bar can either be a generic phrase, for example â€œFetching assetsâ€¦â€, or it can indicate an exact amount of something to be completed, for example â€œ42/256 itemsâ€.
When indicating a loading percentage, the percentage number should count up as the bar progresses.
Helper text could include warning or error message.
Helper text can break and wrap to additional line. However it is recommended to keep it simple as possible.

Usable examples

Related Components

Spinner

For tasks that take bigger real estate and task, such as loading a page or big section card, use a Spinner
